title: Phoenix area may see snow flurries, low temps on Monday
summary:
CLOSEMetro Phoenix might see snow flurries on Monday, according to National Weather Service Phoenix.
As Alaska is dealing with one of its coldest winters ever, the cold air is moving toward Arizona and a cold front will sweep the area early next week, the weather service said.
"This is relatively uncommon, but not unprecedented," said Marvin Percha with the weather service.
Though Percha doesn't expect much snow to fall in Phoenix, he does recommend that people brace themselves for temperatures in the lower 30s and upper 20s throughout next week.
Officials recommend that people keep their plants and pets as warm as possible.

title: Hundreds of people will go pantsless on Phoenix light rail trains this Sunday. Here's why
summary:
CLOSEImagine dozens of passengers boarding light rail trains across metro Phoenix acting like everything is business as usual, except they’re all wearing underwear in lieu of pants.
The tradition started with Jeff Moriarty and 80 others who celebrated the new Valley Metro light rail system in 2009 with a pantsless ride in solidarity with Improv Everywhere’s No Pants Subway Ride.
CLOSE Light rail riders took off their pants for the 11th annual No Pants Light Rail Ride.
There are few things that connect a group of people like taking your pants off in the sunshine.”How to join the No Pants Light Rail RidePantsless riders will pay their fares and board the light rail at the following locations around 1 p.m. Sunday:From west Phoenix: Board at the 19th Avenue/Dunlap Avenue station and head eastbound.

title: NOW HIRING: M Culinary looking to hire 350 people to work 2020 Waste Management Phoenix Open
summary:
PHOENIX — One of the biggest spring events in the Valley -- the Waste Management Phoenix Open -- is less than two weeks away and M Culinary Concepts, the catering company that handles some of the concessions for the golf tournament, is looking to hire 350 people to help work the week-long event.
M Culinary said it is looking to fill 350 positions, including buffet attendants and runners, cooks, prep cooks, and servers.
Applicants should be comfortable being on their feet all day, carrying pans of food, and have a valid food handlers card or certificate, and be available to work the open, which runs Jan. 27 - Feb. 2.

However, the Phoenix Open will have free admission on the first two days of the tournament, Jan. 27 & 28.

title: For $246, you can drive the 'Mortymobile' for a day in Phoenix
summary:
PHOENIX — Fans of the animated TV show, Rick and Morty, have another opportunity to showcase their fandom when the "Mortymobile" drives its way into Phoenix this weekend.
Unlike the Rickmobile, which visited the Valley last year, the Mortymobile is not a pop-up store and does not sell themed merchandise.
For $246, plus a security deposit, people can book the vehicle and drive it around for a day (you do have to be at least 30 years old to book).
The Mortymobile will be available for rent in the Phoenix area between Jan. 18-25, 2020.
According to Turo's website, the Mortymobile gets 29 miles per gallon, has five seats, and requires a clearance of at least eight feet.

Phoenix Fire Department officials say the crash occurred near 15th and Yale streets, near the major cross streets of 16th Street and Thomas Road.
An officer at the scene tells ABC15 that five people were in an SUV that crashed into a brick wall at the scene.
Officials treated six patients, including four people in critical condition, at the crash scene and took them to the hospital.

title: Police Release Person Of Interest Photos In Phoenix Homicide Case
summary:
PHOENIX, AZ — Phoenix police recently released photos of a person of interest in a shooting death that happened Saturday around 8 a.m. Phoenix Fire medics were called to a parking lot in the area of 3400 W. Dunlap Ave. on report of a shooting.
At the scene, medics pronounced a shot man dead.
The suspect left the scene after the shooting, headed east on Dunlap Avenue in a light-colored passenger car.
Meanwhile, an unidentified man whose photos were released recently by Phoenix police has been named a person of interest in the case.
Police are asking anyone who can identify this person of interest or anyone with any knowledge of this case to call the Phoenix Police Department Violent Crimes Bureau at 602-262-6141.

title: AAITA Announces Arizona American Indian Festival 2020
summary:
On Saturday, February 8 from 10:00 a.m. to 6:00 p.m. and Sunday, February 9 from 10:00 a.m. to 4:00 p.m., the Arizona American Indian Tourism Association (AAITA) — in partnership with Arizona’s 22 Native American tribes along with the City of Scottsdale — hosts its annual Arizona Indian Festival.

title: Army Corps of Engineers aids Arizona as coronavirus outbreak continues
summary:
PHOENIX (AP) — Officials from Arizona’s health department and the U.S. Army Corps of Engineers spent hours Wednesday scouring a shuttered Phoenix hospital to see how quickly it could be running if an expected surge of coronavirus cases hits.
“Even if they can do that by 50%, that would be another 8,000 beds potentially and another 700 ICU beds,” Health Services Department Director Dr. Cara Christ said.
State health officials confirmed late Tuesday a sixth virus-related death — a Coconino County man in his 50s with an underlying health condition.
At St. Luke’s in Phoenix, about two dozen staff from the Army Corps, health department and hospital engineering went through the nine-story building, checking air conditioning, electrical, plumbing and oxygen systems.
He said the most important thing isn’t necessarily hospital capacity, but the public’s ability to slow the virus spread by using good hygiene and social distancing.

title: ON Semiconductor donates 10,000 masks to help fight coronavirus
summary:
Phoenix-based ON Semiconductor Corp. donated 10,000 face masks Thursday morning to kick off the city of Phoenix’s personal protective equipment donation drive for health care workers and first responders.
ON Semiconductor donated 8,500 N95 masks and 1,500 ActiveAir masks, half of which will be given to the city of Phoenix and the other half to Banner Health Foundation to help during the coronavirus pandemic.
The Fortune 500 semiconductor supplier company was able to buy the extra masks through its global supply chain, said Jean Chong, vice president of ethics and corporate social responsibility for ON Semiconductor.
“We were able to secure some additional masks so we decided it would be kind to donate them to help health care providers and the front liners,” said Chong, who was on hand when the masks were delivered Thursday morning to Phoenix Mayor Kate Gallego.

title: Arizona Boom Draws Californians and Changes Political Hue
summary:
On the surface, adding new people and new subdivisions is the same thing the Arizona economy was doing as the real estate bubble inflated.
But the nature of Arizona’s growth — and the kinds of workers it has attracted — has changed.
The recent expansion, on the other hand, is marked by the growth of finance and technology companies that employ people like Mr. Jordan.
Technology companies have expanded their head count by about 30 percent in that time, while construction employment is still 24 percent lower than its peak before the recession.
If construction and subprime loans were symbolic of the state’s last boom, this time the image would be offices like WebPT, which makes software used by physical therapists and rehabilitation specialists to manage billing and medical information.

title: Phoenix area to see rain in waves all week starting Monday night
summary:
CLOSEThe Phoenix area can expect to see rain over the next few days as a weather system will be stationed in the eastern Pacific, according to meteorologist Issac Smith of the National Weather Service in Phoenix.
The light rain will start to affect the state and move into metro Phoenix late Monday night and into early Tuesday, according to Smith.
The rain will be light to moderate, and metro Phoenix is expected to receive the rain in several waves, as opposed to long periods of showers, Smith said.
Rain totals are expected to be three quarters of an inch to one and three quarters of an inch.
Meteorologists say another system coming down from the Pacific Northwest will also bring showers to Arizona starting next week.

title: Valley nonprofit CEO who worked to help black families, children dies
summary:
Mary M. Black, who founded and was the longtime CEO of the Black Family and Child Services of Arizona, died last week.
Black started the organization in 1984 and spent more than 35 years leading it before she retired in October 2019.
Shawn Pearson, a 25-year nonprofit veteran, took over as CEO of the organization in January.
Black’s pioneering work touched and improved the lives of thousands of children and families throughout the course of her amazing career,” Pearson said in a statement.

That reversed the strongest 9-month-stretch of year-over-year inventory growth – from October 2018 to June 2019 – in report history.

title: Phoenix retail market healthy despite national struggles
summary:
The Greater Phoenix retail market is performing well, despite the national trend of retail struggles, according to a report from Colliers International.
The Airport Area and Northwest Phoenix submarkets have been attracting businesses, driving demand for retail space and pushing down vacancy rates.
Net absorption of retail space in the Greater Phoenix retail market fell into negative territory during the first quarter.
Since 2015, Greater Phoenix asking rental rates for retail space have increased nearly 15 percent, with much of the growth occurring since 2017.
Sustained population and job growth in Greater Phoenix, the healthy local economy and bolstered tourism are helping to fuel a more robust retail outlook.

title: Uber announces last day of transport to/from Phoenix Sky Harbor Airport
summary:
Uber's decision to pull out of Sky Harbor follows a fee increase approved by the Phoenix City Council in October 2019.
In December 2019, Uber sent a letter to Valley drivers announcing the drivers would no longer have the option to be able pick-up or drop-off passengers at Sky Harbor.
""We are writing to let you know that Phoenix Sky Harbor International Airport (PHX) recently imposed a new airport rideshare fee of $4 per trip," Uber wrote in a the email.
The city said the increase was long overdue after Sky Harbor made the decision to cut the fee in recent years.
This new fee puts Sky Harbor among the priciest rideshare airports in the country.

title: 2 meteor showers will play across the Arizona skies this week
summary:
October opens up the fall meteor shower season with the annual Draconid shower.
This interesting meteor shower will appear all week in our Arizona skies and peak on the nights of Oct. 8-9.
The Draconid meteor shower is known to come from comet 21P/Giacobini–Zinner, discovered back on Dec. 20, 1900.
The other meteor shower that is plowing into our October skies is the annual Southern Taurid meteor shower.
Alert: Look to the early evening and midnight skies for what may be a few very bright fireballs from these two showers.

This monument, designed by Phoenix artist Maureen McGuire, was the first structure built on the Irish Cultural Center site in 1999.

title: Leonid Meteor Shower Peak: Viewing Tips In Phoenix
summary:
PHOENIX, AZ — We suggest you cue Katie Melua's "Blame It On The Moon" when you're searching the sky during the Leonid meteor shower, which peaks overnight this Sunday and Monday.
The best viewing times for the Leonid meteor shower are after midnight and before dawn.
The meteor shower occurs when the Earth crosses the orbital path of Comet 55P/Tempel-Tuttle, which litters its orbital path with debris.
The parent comet releases fresh debris with every orbit, increasing the likelihood of a meteor storm.
Spaceweather.com reported another Leonid meteor storm occurred in 2001, when "thousands of meteors an hour rained over North America and Hawaii."

title: EPA Data: Phoenix Has Highest Levels in U.S. of Carcinogenic Gas Ethylene Oxide
summary:
New data from the Environmental Protection Agency indicate that concentrations of ethylene oxide, a colorless and carcinogenic gas, are higher in Phoenix than anywhere else in the country.
Both measured well above the national average of 0.297 micrograms of ethylene oxide per cubic meter.
Ethylene oxide is an industrial compound most commonly used to produce other chemicals, like antifreeze.
"We believe that there is no immediate, short-term risk from the levels of ethylene oxide found in these limited air monitoring data," it said in a news release.
"There is a need to better understand low levels of ethylene oxide over a longer-term period."

title: Arizona Supreme Court upholds Sky Harbor Airport rideshare fee
summary:
PHOENIX — The Arizona Supreme Court has upheld a Phoenix city ordinance that applies an additional fee to rideshare services to and from Sky Harbor Airport.
Uber had threatened to pull out of Sky Harbor following the announcement of the fee increase approved by the Phoenix City Council in October 2019.
"We are writing to let you know that Phoenix Sky Harbor International Airport (PHX) recently imposed a new airport rideshare fee of $4 per trip," Uber wrote in a the email.
The city said the increase was long overdue after Sky Harbor made the decision to cut the fee in recent years.
This new fee puts Sky Harbor among the priciest rideshare airports in the country.

title: Phoenix's biggest weather events of 2019 didn't involve heat. Here's what they were
summary:

The average high temperature for February (63.6 degrees) was 7.1 degrees below normal.
Summer was hot, but not that hotThere were no eye-catching high temperatures in 2019 — nothing like the 122-degree high Phoenix experienced on June 26, 1990.
That wouldn’t even crack the top five on the city’s all-time high temperature list.
The city also saw six high temperature records either beaten or tied during the spring and summer, in addition to five records for warmest overnight low temperatures.

It commemorates the reclamation of the Jerusalem Holy Temple from the Greeks by a small group of Jews, and it celebrates the temple's rededication thereafter, according to Chabad.org.

title: Camelback Christmas tree is back. Here's why it's controversial, and when you can see it
summary:
An intrepid group of volunteers, including John “Camelback Santa” Cressey, have placed a Christmas tree atop Camelback Mountain in Phoenix.
This year the tree will be placed atop the mountain each morning leading up to Christmas.
On weekends, Camelback Santa will hand out candy canes or coal (depending on which list you’re on) and pose for photos with anyone who’s interested.
“For me, it’s become a tradition for people to come up and see Camelback Santa and get their picture taken with him,” Cressey said.
“The birds and ground squirrels on Camelback love the tree and feast on it,” Cressey said.

title: 216 UFO Sightings In Arizona So Far In 2019: What They Saw
summary:
ARIZONA – The National UFO Reporting Center gets witness accounts of unidentified flying objects every year from people in Arizona and elsewhere around the country.
Thousands of reports of unidentified flying objects, or UFOs, are filed every year.
In Arizona, while the clock ticks down to Jan. 1, 2020, so far 216 reports have been filed in 2019.
Meanwhile the city of Phoenix had 5 UFO sightings reported in December, the most recent of which happened on Dec. 20 and was reported the same day.
Read more Arizona UFO reports at the National UFO Reporting Center's website.

title: Rent In Arizona: Prices Climbed In 2019
summary:
ARIZONA — Rent costs are on the rise across the nation, according to the first National Rent Report of 2020, compiled by Apartment List.
Nationally, rent costs increased 1.4 percent from December 2018 to December 2019; however, some cities actually are bucking the trend and seeing rent costs fall.
Arizona is among the states where rent costs increased in 2019.
According to the report, rent increased 3.5 percent from December 2018 to December 2019.
According to the report, Mesa, Arizona, had the fastest year-over-year rent growth among cities with a population of 250,000 or more.

title: Phoenix has first wet Christmas since 2008; more rain on way
summary:
PHOENIX – Usually, Phoenix residents who prefer precipitation can only dream of a wet Christmas.
Phoenix Sky Harbor International Airport saw .22 inches of rain Wednesday, the first measurable Christmas Day precipitation in more than a decade, according to the National Weather Service.
The city saw rainfall on the date for the first time since 2008 and just the 15th time ever recorded, the agency said.
Most of the Valley got wet Wednesday, with some areas getting two or three times more rain than the airport.
Southwest AZ and Southeast CA could get more rain than Phoenix!

title: Phoenix 2019 weather wrap-up: It felt like a cool, dry year. But was it?
summary:
CLOSEAt first glance, 2019 looked like a cool, dry, just-about-average year for Phoenix.
The first three months of the year were cool, with an average temperature of 58.7 degrees.
May was another cool month (the average temperature of 76.2 was 5.9 degrees below normal) before things began to heat up over the summer.
Though the year overall was close to normal, those cool months stood out when compared to recent history.

title: Phoenix man smoked meth with victim before shooting him in the head, police say
summary:
CLOSEPhoenix police car (Photo: The Republic)A man was arrested in west Phoenix on Friday on suspicion of first-degree murder, according to court documents.
Gary Lee Frank, 46, reportedly smoked methamphetamine with the victim and asked him to give back the money he lent him before shooting him, according to court documents.
Once there, they began to smoke methamphetamine and Frank demanded money from the victim, witnesses told police.
On Dec. 14, 2019, officers responded to a call of a dead person and found the victim in the home, court documents said.
During the investigation, two witnesses told police that it was Frank who shot the victim, who police did not name.

title: Arizona has tried to safeguard groundwater beneath its big cities. But things are about to change
summary:
While groundwater is rapidly falling in rural farming communities across Arizona, Phoenix, Tucson and other cities haven’t reached that desperate situation.
Water levels in some of the wells surrounding these recharge sites have jumped 150 to 200 feet since the early 1980s.
Starting next year, though, there will be much less of that river water available to prop up aquifers.
Mark Henle/The RepublicThe Colorado River is under increasing pressures due to years of overuse and drought, compounded by the effects of climate change.
In 1996, the Central Arizona Project started sending Colorado River water to groundwater replenishment ponds to boost aquifer levels.

title: Sumitomo buys Collier Center in Downtown Phoenix
summary:
Sumitomo Corporation of Americas (SCOA) announced today their purchase of the Collier Center, a 2.8-acre commercial complex located in downtown Phoenix, Arizona.
This is SCOA’s second commercial real estate investment this year, having acquired SPS Tower in Minneapolis this past February.
Collier Center is currently at 84% occupancy with Bank of America and Uber among its largest tenants.
“We are very excited to add Collier Center to our growing portfolio of commercial real estate investments throughout the United States,” said Yurika Sugimoto, Manager in the Commercial Real Estate Unit at Sumitomo Corporation of Americas.
With this new acquisition, Sumitomo Corporation of Americas owns a commercial real estate portfolio totaling over $425 million to date with over 1.6 million square feet of commercial space.

summary:
Hines, the international real estate firm, announced today it will host a groundbreaking ceremony for its new Downtown Phoenix luxury multifamily complex Adeline—its first multifamily property in the Phoenix market—on January 14, 2020.
Phoenix Mayor Kate Gallego, Councilmember Michael Nowakowski and City of Phoenix Community and Economic Development Director Christine Mackay are scheduled to speak along with Chris Anderson, senior managing director and Arizona leader for Hines.
Hines’ new 25-story, 379-unit luxury multifamily complex will feature an urban courtyard, junior Olympic-size swimming pool, and clubhouse, providing luxury living at its finest in downtown Phoenix near Talking Stick Resort Arena and the new downtown Fry’s grocery store.

title: Trump impeachment rally draws hundreds outside Phoenix office of McSally
summary:
CLOSEHundreds rallied near the office of Sen. Martha McSally on Tuesday as part of a national movement to call for President Donald Trump's impeachment and removal from office.
Demonstrators chanted calls for Trump to leave office amid bass drum beats and a constant chorus of car horns blaring in response to multiple protest signs reading "Honk for impeachment."
Some came with signs, megaphones, and balloons — one man in a group of a couple dozen counter-protesters held up a massive Trump 2020 flag.
The obstruction of Congress charge accuses the president of directing officials not to comply with subpoenas related to the House’s impeachment inquiry.
CLOSE Protesters rallied outside the office of Martha McSally as part of a national movement to call for President Trump's impeachment.
